frameDefinitions: An Agent causes an Impactor to make sudden, forcible contact with an Impactee, or manipulates two (or more) Impactors so that they make mutual forcible contact.
This frame pertains to noise verbs used to characterize motion.
A physical entity, construed as a point-Sound_source, emits a Sound.
A Location is filled or covered with the Theme.
An Agent adjusts an Instrument to enable it to interact directly with a difficult-to-access Target_location.
This frame contains words for types of noise which can be used to characterize verbal communication.
frameExamples: He <t>slammed</t> his fist down on the table and bellowed something unintelligible.
The waters of the bay <t>teemed</t> with fish.
If you <t>aim</t> your weapons somewhere else , I 'll be more likely to talk .
'Don't treat me as a child!' she <t>cried</t> scornfully.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Impactee</fen> is the entity which is hit by the <fen>Impactor</fen>.
The <fen>Impactor</fen> is the entity that hits the <fen>Impactee</fen> because of the <fen>Agent</fen>'s efforts.
The <fen>Impactors</fen> are the multiple entities that collide.
The <fen>Agent</fen>  causes an impact.

The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, 
typically non-human, force that causes an <fen>Impactor</fen> to make sudden, 
forcible contact with an Impactee.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen>  when the impact occurs.
Where the event takes place.

The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location.  In sentences containing a <fen>Cause</fen>, the <fen>Theme</fen> is typically the NP Object.  In other sentences, the <fen>Theme</fen> is normally the External Argument.
The <fen>Source</fen> is any expression which implies a definite starting-point of Motion.
The <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is any expression which tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the Motion.
This role identifies the general <fen>Area</fen> in which motion takes place, used particularly if the motion is understood as following a complex or non-linear path.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the motion event takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location of a more specific motion (which has <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, <fen>Goal</fen>, or <fen>Area</fen>).

The frame element <fen>Sound_source</fen> is assigned to a constituent referring to a physical entity which emits a sound. Such an entity must have an appropriately complex internal structure such that it can create a sound. For example, a machine or some other thing with moving parts can create sound by itself.

The frame element <fen>Sound</fen> is incorporated in the meaning of the verbs of this frame. Otherwise, this role is assigned to NPs which actually refer to a sound in the presence of the target. This typically occurs when the target is a verb used as a modifier in its <ment>-ing</ment> form, e.g.:
An event in which one or more <fen>Sound_source</fen>s participate and which is accompanied by <fen>Sound</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Noisy_event</fen> occurs.

The location of the <fen>Sound_source</fen>. This role differs from <fen>Location_of_source</fen> only in terms of point of view; the latter role implies a point of view that is not on the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
The <fen>Theme</fen> covers or fills the <fen>Location</fen>.  This role most frequently occurs in a PP Complement headed by with or in.
<fen>Location</fen> is the object or area that the <fen>Theme</fen> fills or covers.  This frame element generally occurs as the External Argument.
The period of time during which the the Abounding_with event occurs.
The individual that manipulates the <fen>Instrument</fen> to enable interaction with the <fen>Targeted</fen>.
The <fen>Targeted</fen> is the entity located in an indirectly accessible location relative to the <fen>Agent</fen>.
The object manipulated by the <fen>Agent</fen> in order to interact with the <fen>Targeted</fen>.
The location that the <fen>Agent</fen> wishes to ready the <fen>Instrument</fen> to access.
The <fen>Activity</fen> is undertaken by the <fen>Agent</fen> and is directed towards the <fen>Targeted</fen> or <fen>Target_location</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> takes aim.
The place where the <fen>Agent</fen> aims at the <fen>Targeted</fen>.
<fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that delivers the <fen>Message</fen>.
Message has a number of different realizations in this frame, including <ment>that</ment>-clauses, direct quotes, infinitival complements, <ment>for-to</ment> phrases, and NP Objects.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs in PP Complements, usually headed by <ment>about</ment>.
The <fen>Voice</fen> describes the <fex name=''>Speaker'</fex>s utterance or other message-encoded production.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> where the Communication noise event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an event occurs.
listRoleExamples: What I want to know is who smacked <fex>my head</fex> with a 10-ton truck?
Those hoodlums strike my car <fex>with water balloons</fex> every day!
Mr. Addams likes to collide <fex>toy trains</fex> at high speed.
<fex>One juggler</fex> was hitting the ceiling with every other ball.
<fex>A violent explosion</fex>rattled the windows.
A postman rammed his Fiat Panda into a getaway car <fex>after spotting the burglars </fex> .
Father Shanahan , of Rushey Mead , Leicester , rammed his Datsun into another car <fex>on the way to the city 's Gilroes cemetery</fex>.
<fex>Pat</fex> crunched over the fresh snow.
The train rumbled <fex>out of the station</fex>.
The truck roared <fex>through the tunnel</fex>.
The plates clattered <fex>to the floor</fex>.
The fly buzzed <fex>about the room</fex>.
The train screeched into the station <fex>at half past seven</fex>
<fex>The wind</fex> howled.
The branches made a rattling <fex>sound</fex>.
<fex>The conversations</fex> droned on
It's going to beep again <fex>in two minutes</fex>.
A bat squeaked <fex>over our heads</fex>.
The waters of the bay teemed <fex>with fish</fex>.
<fex>The walls</fex> crawled with nanite surveillance probes.
I tried to target <fex>his left thigh</fex> .
If you target <fex>towards the bridge</fex> , make sure to avoid the church .
<fex>The attack</fex> targeted a village south of here.
<fex>Kim</fex> whined that it wasn't fair.
Kim whined <fex>that it wasn't fair</fex>.
Kim howled <fex>about the unfairness of it all</fex>.
<fex>John's voice</fex> bellowed for her to be quiet.
